title: Sewage treatment and Municipal Solid Waste

content.question: Respond to parts A, B, C, and all subparts. (a) Many countries now use centralized sewage treatment plants to treat the wastewater from houses and businesses. (i) Describe a main goal of primary treatment in a modern sewage treatment plant.

frqParts.text: Respond to parts A, B, C, and all subparts. (a) Many countries now use centralized sewage treatment plants to treat the wastewater from houses and businesses. (i) Describe a main goal of primary treatment in a modern sewage treatment plant.
(ii) Describe a main goal of secondary treatment in a modern sewage treatment plant.
(iii) Many sewage treatment plants use tertiary treatment as the final step in wastewater treatment. Describe one advantage of this process.

(iv) If a sewage treatment plant malfunctions or if low-income areas lack sanitary waste disposal, raw sewage can be introduced into surface waterways. Describe one potential environmental problem or one potential human health problem that can result from the presence of raw sewage in surface waters.
(v) Identify one water parameter that could be measured to determine whether raw sewage is present in surface waterways.

(b) The United States Environmental Protection Agency (<math alttext="E P A " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>EPA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) refers to the trash or garbage that can be placed in landfills (landfilled) as municipal solid waste (<math alttext="M S W " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). <math alttext="M S W " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can include such items as bottles, cardboard boxes, food, grass clippings, furniture, tires, computers, and appliances. The total <math alttext="M S W " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> generated and the total <math alttext="M S W " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> landfilled from 1960 to 2015 in the United States are shown in the graph below. (i) Describe the trend in total <math alttext="M S W " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> generated from 1960 to 2015.

(ii) Compare the trends in the total <math alttext="M S W " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> generated and the total <math alttext="M S W " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> landfilled between 1990 and 2000.

(iii) Explain a probable reason for the trend in the total <math alttext="M S W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>MSW</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> landfilled described in (b)(ii).

(c) One environmental problem in landfills is that organic materials such as food scraps and yard waste can decompose and produce methane over time. Methane is flammable and can be very dangerous in large concentrations.(i) Propose a solution to reduce the risk of flammable methane from concentrating in landfills.
(ii) Justify your solution proposed in (c)(i) by explaining an additional benefit to the solution besides reducing the amount of flammable methane concentrating in the landfill.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Describe environmental concepts and processes.
